ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I really appreciated the cross-functional exploration of military strategy, history, and technology, and how these elements work together. I gained a valuable understanding of how these concepts fit together in the past, and how to apply some of Professor Brackens framing concepts for future problems

Good historical knowledge and frameworks to think about how technology impacts war/strategy, and vice versa. I'm definitely walking away from the course feeling more confident in my abilities to think about technology in a business context.

Thinking about complex problems and the role of leadership/management,
Understanding of nuance in modern conflicts
A lot of management concepts and theories, as well as simple concepts that fit into historical and current war strategies.

Learned about the cold war and nuclear weapon strategy. Learned also about various management techniques like first order controls and BCG matrix. Learned a lot about WWII and various other cool historical and technological developments.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: More discussion with the students
great course!
The professor is extremely knowledgeable but I believe the course could be greatly improved with more structure.

Strengths:

Very interesting subject matter

Prof Bracken has fascinating experiences and is a good lecturer - a lot of the fun of the course was in hearing some of his stories

Good examples and case studies to illustrate concepts

Weaknesses:

The evaluation system. The two exams felt weak and there was no other grade other than participation, which seems hard to measure on Zoom.
Not  very engaging virtually, would likely be better in person
Lectures were very interesting but test was unnecessarily hard
There is limited interaction between professor and students. The syllabus makes no mention of a final exam and is inaccurate.

Strength is definitely Professor Bracken's lectures. Weakness is that the midterm and final were the only assignments. I'd definitely benefit from more periodic evaluations of knowledge, such as short Canvas quizzes or homeworks to apply the knowledge we learned.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It went very well all things considered
This was a good class despite COVID-19.
The ability to listen to recorded lectures was helpful
The online lecture style made it difficult to focus

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes. This is a really interesting course that covers a relevant topic.

I would because it's interesting and Prof Bracken is very cool, but the exams need to be changed. I felt like they didn't assess me on key concepts from the lectures/readings and were too memory-based.
Yes, if youre interested in the strategic dimensions of war and technology. Good guy to enjoy basically

Not at all, unless they credit/D/fail it. The course provides limited space for feedback and the class material is not what is on the exams. It is not a "difficult" course,  but as it is a grad school course, it is difficult to get an A or high B.
Yes! Very good for learning about the landscape of technology and war in the 20th and 21st century. One of my favorite classes I've taken at Yale.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: The lecture was recorded
Lectures were also recorded
